message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emergent coexistence in multispecies microbial communities
Paper Abstract: Understanding the mechanisms that maintain microbial biodiversity is a critical aspiration in ecology. Past work on microbial coexistence has largely focused on species pairs, but it is unclear whether pairwise coexistence in isolation is required for coexistence in a multispecies community. To address this question, we conducted hundreds of pairwise competition experiments among the stably coexisting members of 12 different enrichment communities in vitro. To determine the outcomes of these experiments, we developed an automated image analysis pipeline to quantify species abundances. We found that competitive exclusion was the most common outcome, and it was strongly hierarchical and transitive. Because many species that coexist within a stable multispecies community fail to coexist in pairwise co-culture under identical conditions, we concluded that multispecies coexistence is an emergent phenomenon. This work highlights the importance of community context for understanding the origins of coexistence in complex ecosystems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "ecology". Here are the key findings:

## Definition
Ecology is a branch of biology, and is the study of abundance, biomass, and distribution of organisms in the context of the environment.(no content)The term ecology was coined in 1866 by the German scientist Ernst Haeckel.

## Core Concepts
Ecosystems are dynamically interacting systems of organisms, the communities they make up, and the non-living (abiotic) components of their environment.(no content)Ecosystem processes, such as primary production, nutrient cycling, and niche construction, regulate the flux of energy and matter through an environment.

## Related Disciplines
Ecology overlaps with the closely related sciences of biogeography, evolutionary biology, genetics, ethology, and natural history.

## History
The science of ecology as we know it today began with a group of American botanists in the 1890s.

## Ecosystem Services
Ecosystems provide ecosystem services like biomass production (food, fuel, fiber, and medicine), the regulation of climate, global biogeochemical cycles, water filtration, soil formation, and erosion control.

The search results also covered specialized fields like community ecology, organizational ecology, and human behavioral ecology, along with topics like ecosystem regeneration and dead zones in aquatic systems.

## Definition
Ecology is a branch of biology, and is the study of abundance, biomass, and distribution of organisms in the context of the environment.(no content)The term ecology was coined in 1866 by the German scientist Ernst Haeckel.

## Core Concepts
Ecosystems are dynamically interacting systems of organisms, the communities they make up, and the non-living (abiotic) components of their environment.(no content)Ecosystem processes, such as primary production, nutrient cycling, and niche construction, regulate the flux of energy and matter through an environment.

## Related Disciplines
Ecology overlaps with the closely related sciences of biogeography, evolutionary biology, genetics, ethology, and natural history.

## History
The science of ecology as we know it today began with a group of American botanists in the 1890s.

## Ecosystem Services
Ecosystems provide ecosystem services like biomass production (food, fuel, fiber, and medicine), the regulation of climate, global biogeochemical cycles, water filtration, soil formation, and erosion control.

Here are the search results for "image analysis":

## Overview

Image analysis is the extraction of meaningful information from images, mainly from digital images by means of digital image processing techniques.(no content)Image analysis tasks can be as simple as reading bar coded tags or as sophisticated as identifying a person from their face.

## Key Aspects

**Scope and Methods:**
Image analysis involves the fields of computer or machine vision, and medical imaging, and makes heavy use of pattern recognition, digital geometry, and signal processing.(no content)This field of computer science developed in the 1950s at academic institutions such as the MIT A.I. Lab, originally as a branch of artificial intelligence and robotics.

**Applications:**
The applications of digital image analysis are continuously expanding through all areas of science and industry, including anatomy (allowing for precise measurements, visualization, and statistical analysis of anatomical structures), assay micro plate reading, and astronomy (such as calculating the size of a planet).

**Specialized Approaches:**
Object-based image analysis involves two typical processes, segmentation and classification, and has been applied in many fields such as cell biology, medicine, earth sciences, and remote sensing.

The search results provide comprehensive information about various aspects of image analysis, including medical imaging, microscopy, tissue analysis, and more specialized applications across different scientific and industrial fields.

Web search results for query: "species coexistence ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Coexistence theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coexistence_theory"},{"title":"Storage effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storage_effect"},{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_differentiation"},{"title":"Coexistence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coexistence"},{"title":"Limiting similarity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limiting_similarity"},{"title":"Relative nonlinearity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_nonlinearity"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowding_out_(biology)"},{"title":"Hutchinson's rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hutchinson's_rule"}]

I've searched for information on species coexistence ecology. Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Species Coexistence

Coexistence theory explains the stable coexistence of species as an interaction between two opposing forces: fitness differences between species, which should drive the best-adapted species to exclude others within a particular ecological niche, and stabilizing mechanisms, which maintains diversity.

## Fundamental Principles

The competitive exclusion principle proposes that species cannot coexist if they have the same ecological niche. However, competitive exclusion is rarely observed in natural ecosystems, and many biological communities appear to violate Gause's law.

## Key Mechanisms for Coexistence

Two qualitatively different processes can help species to coexist: a reduction in average fitness differences between species or an increase in niche differentiation between species. These two factors have been termed equalizing and stabilizing mechanisms, respectively.(no content)Resource partitioning (a type of niche differentiation) is a stabilizing mechanism because interspecific competition is reduced when different species primarily compete for different resources.(no content)The storage effect is a coexistence mechanism proposed in the ecological theory of species coexistence, which tries to explain how such a wide variety of similar species are able to coexist within the same ecological community or guild. The storage effect was originally proposed in the 1980s to explain coexistence in diverse communities of coral reef fish.

These search results provide comprehensive information about the ecological principles, mechanisms, and theories governing how multiple species can coexist in shared environments.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "biodiversity"

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Global biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_biodiversity"},{"title":"Biodiversity offsetting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_offsetting"},{"title":"Biodiversity hotspot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot"},{"title":"National Biodiversity Centre (Singapore) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Biodiversity_Centre_(Singapore)"},{"title":"List of biodiversity databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_biodiversity_databases"},{"title":"Global Biodiversity Information Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Biodiversity_Information_Facility"},{"title":"Human Biodiversity Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Biodiversity_Institute"},{"title":"Food biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_biodiversity"},{"title":"Yamuna biodiversity park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamuna_biodiversity_park"}]

Here are the search results for "biodiversity":

## Definition and Overview

Biodiversity is the variability of life on Earth.(no content)It can be measured on various levels, for example, genetic variability, species diversity, ecosystem diversity and phylogenetic diversity.

## Current Species and Estimates

Estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 2 million to 1 trillion, but most estimates are around 11 million species or fewer.(no content)According to estimates by Mora et al. (2011), there are approximately 8.7 million terrestrial species and 2.2 million oceanic species.

## Biodiversity Loss Crisis

Human activities have led to an ongoing biodiversity loss and an accompanying loss of genetic diversity, often referred to as Holocene extinction, or the sixth mass extinction.(no content)The planet has lost 58% of its biodiversity since 1970 according to a 2016 study by the World Wildlife Fund.

## Main Causes

Destroying habitats for farming is a key reason why biodiversity is decreasing today.(no content)Habitat destruction (often for expansion of agriculture) is currently the bigger driver of biodiversity loss than climate change.

## Biodiversity Hotspots

A biodiversity hotspot is a biogeographic region with significant levels of biodiversity that is threatened by human habitation.(no content)These sites support nearly 60% of the world's plant, bird, mammal, reptile, and amphibian species, with a high share of those species as endemics, and host their diverse ecosystems on just 2.4% of the planet's surface.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Global biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_biodiversity"},{"title":"Biodiversity offsetting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_offsetting"},{"title":"Biodiversity hotspot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot"},{"title":"National Biodiversity Centre (Singapore) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Biodiversity_Centre_(Singapore)"},{"title":"List of biodiversity databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_biodiversity_databases"},{"title":"Global Biodiversity Information Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Biodiversity_Information_Facility"},{"title":"Human Biodiversity Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Biodiversity_Institute"},{"title":"Food biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_biodiversity"},{"title":"Yamuna biodiversity park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamuna_biodiversity_park"}]

Here are the search results for "biodiversity":

## Definition and Overview

Biodiversity is the variability of life on Earth.(no content)It can be measured on various levels, for example, genetic variability, species diversity, ecosystem diversity and phylogenetic diversity.

## Current Species and Estimates

Estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 2 million to 1 trillion, but most estimates are around 11 million species or fewer.(no content)According to estimates by Mora et al. (2011), there are approximately 8.7 million terrestrial species and 2.2 million oceanic species.

## Biodiversity Loss Crisis

Human activities have led to an ongoing biodiversity loss and an accompanying loss of genetic diversity, often referred to as Holocene extinction, or the sixth mass extinction.(no content)The planet has lost 58% of its biodiversity since 1970 according to a 2016 study by the World Wildlife Fund.

## Main Causes

Destroying habitats for farming is a key reason why biodiversity is decreasing today.(no content)Habitat destruction (often for expansion of agriculture) is currently the bigger driver of biodiversity loss than climate change.

## Biodiversity Hotspots

A biodiversity hotspot is a biogeographic region with significant levels of biodiversity that is threatened by human habitation.(no content)These sites support nearly 60% of the world's plant, bird, mammal, reptile, and amphibian species, with a high share of those species as endemics, and host their diverse ecosystems on just 2.4% of the planet's surface.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "competitive exclusion principle"

Links: [{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"Paradox of the plankton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradox_of_the_plankton"},{"title":"Limiting similarity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limiting_similarity"},{"title":"Exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exclusion_principle"},{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Talk:Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"Interspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interspecific_competition"},{"title":"Coexistence theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coexistence_theory"},{"title":"Category:Biological interactions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Biological_interactions"},{"title":"Competition law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_busting"}]

Based on the search results, here's what the competitive exclusion principle is:

## Definition

The competitive exclusion principle, sometimes referred to as Gause's law, is a proposition that two species which compete for the same limited resource cannot coexist at constant population sizes.(no content)When one species has even the slightest advantage over another, the one with the advantage will dominate in the long term, leading either to the extinction of the weaker competitor or to an evolutionary or behavioral shift toward a different ecological niche.

## History

Based on field observations, Joseph Grinnell formulated the principle of competitive exclusion in 1904: "Two species of approximately the same food habits are not likely to remain long evenly balanced in numbers in the same region. One will crowd out the other".(no content)Georgy Gause formulated the law of competitive exclusion based on laboratory competition experiments using two species of Paramecium, where P. aurelia recovered and subsequently drove P. caudatum extinct via exploitative resource competition.

## Paradox in Nature

Interestingly, for poorly understood reasons, competitive exclusion is rarely observed in natural ecosystems, and many biological communities appear to violate Gause's law.(no content)The best-known example is the so-called "paradox of the plankton": all plankton species live on a very limited number of resources, primarily solar energy and minerals dissolved in the water. According to the competitive exclusion principle, only a small number of plankton species should be able to coexist on these resources. Nevertheless, large numbers of plankton species coexist within small regions of open sea.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "microbial biodiversity"

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Microbial biogeography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_biogeography"},{"title":"Marine microorganisms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_microorganisms"},{"title":"Microecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microecology"},{"title":"Microbial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_ecology"},{"title":"Marine microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_microbiome"},{"title":"Microorganism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microorganism"},{"title":"Ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem"},{"title":"Microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome"},{"title":"Soil biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_biodiversity"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about microbial biodiversity:

## Overview of Microbial Biodiversity

The vast majority of Earth's species are microbial.(no content)Microbial life is metabolically and environmentally more diverse than multicellular life.

## Scale and Diversity

The true extent of microbial biodiversity is still being discovered. A May 2016 estimate gives an estimate of perhaps 1 trillion microbial species on the planet. However, currently, only one-thousandth of one percent of that total have been described.(no content)In 2016, Locey and Lennon estimated the number of microorganism species could be as high as 1 trillion.

## Major Groups

Bacteria are the oldest and most biodiverse group, followed by Archaea and Fungi.(no content)The combined domains of archaea and bacteria make up the most diverse and abundant group of organisms on Earth and inhabit practically all environments where the temperature is below +140 °C (284 °F).

## Ecological Importance

Marine microorganisms have been variously estimated to make up between 70 and 90 percent of the biomass in the ocean.(no content)Microorganisms are responsible for nearly all photosynthesis that occurs in the ocean, as well as the cycling of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and other nutrients and trace elements.

## Biogeography

Microbial biogeography can provide insight into the underlying mechanisms that generate and hinder biodiversity. Interestingly, studies on indoor fungal communities and global topsoil microbiomes found microbial biodiversity to be significantly higher in temperate zones than in the tropics.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
